Once upon a time, I had a strong meditation practice. Any time I found myself somewhere with no positive engagement, like waiting at the DMV, I would meditate. I looked forward to situations with nothing to do. Deep meditation isn't thinking. It's non-thinking. Focusing on the breath in silence or mentally repeating a phrase or mantra creates a separation between "me" and "my thoughts". To claim to be thinking implies volition. If I willfully can't stop thinking, I'm not in charge. Thoughts come whether I like them or not. I would love to stop thinking about my ex.

But I stopped meditating years ago. Sometimes I think I should take up the practice again. But when I do, it just seems too boring.

Lack of boredom is destroying our social and romantic lives. People now report having significantly fewer friends on average than in the 90s, and despite how sex-positive our culture has become, we’re actually having less of it than boomers were in their day. In fact, from 2008 to 2018, only 10 years, the rate of men under 30 who were still virgins went from 8% to 28%. It literally tripled in a single decade which happened to coincide with the rise of social media.

Sometimes, boredom gave us the drive to go out, talk to people, connect, fall in love, etc. when your options were to go to a dance or stare at the wall all night, it was easier to motivate yourself to go out.

Boredom is an alarm that you aren’t doing enough fulfilling things in your life. As unpleasant as it is, we kinda needed that.

Excellent topic. I tend to like to be occupied doing something (including consuming media) all the time, so I have to make an effort to be bored. Here are some suggestions for beneficial boredom:  Get away regularly to a place without your mobile devices or with no cellular signal for at least part of a day if not a weekend or a few days - either by yourself or with someone you are close with. If you have to occasionally occupy yourself during these times, take a boring book that will let your mind wander as you read. My personal favorite is to get away - it is calming and rejuvenating. If you are single and don't like to get away, perhaps you could do a weekly "power off" period for a few hours at a time, when only the essentials are on - refrigerator, AC, lights - and don't neglect to power off your mobile devices or go "airplane mode" and put them in a drawer. This honestly doesn't work at my house though since my wife has different needs and preferences.

My idea is even simpler, animals evolved to be bored, so they don't get "stuck" doing repetitive activities that satisfy their needs. Is not hard to see why that would be bad. Like, if an animal finds an apple tree that gives them all food they want and never get bored of it, they will repeatedly eat from it, and if one day that tree for some reason dies, they would starve to death. So, by becoming bored of it, they will look for other sources of food and will be more adaptable to random events, and therefore will have a better chance of surviving.

Powerful message, I wouldn't nessarilly call all of it boredum, but we do however need to provide time for us to do what many of us avoid, think, thinking without  anything crowding in, demanding a solution from us or to distract us. We simply need to deal with ourselves

So this is a topic I am very interested in. I have taught through the sixth grade in public schools over the last decade. I often try and teach my students the science and reasons behind their behaviors.

I talk to them about Borden essentially being a choice. They have control over what they will be invested in. I have also taught that boredom is not a bad thing.

What I have seen over the last few years are students who are motivated by nothing. Meaning doing nothing is more desirable than doing something.

With what you shared here, these students should be creatively thinking but the problem is they are not. They consume their entire mental space in a video game world our some other area where their ability to independently think its lost.

My honors theater professor gave us several lessons on this. He had us do a writing exercise where we were told to write about something mundane, and just state the facts of the situation. We couldn’t stop writing until we were done with the 15 minute limit. Then after we finished that he asked us to write it like a script staying with the facts of the situation, but adding our emotions to it. Our boredom in the first activity made it a much more enjoyable time working on the script despite the dull prose we had written.

Great video. I think there's an important perspective on boredom that wasn't acknowledged. I see boredom as having an experience of what it's currently like to be you without distraction. People who are feeling more internal distress are more easily bored. People with intense distress can practically never find something to sufficiently drown out their internal pain, whereas in moments of contentment people are more able to sit and just look out their window. From this perspective, being bored doesn't necessarily mean we have to change our outer situation. It might mean that we have to tend to our inner landscape. As a psychologist, I can tell you that the way to heal that pain is to acknowledge and process it.

Hmm. I agree with many of the points presented here. However, I believe that for certain people, especially ones with neurodivergent mental states or afflicted with illnesses such as ADHD, boredom comes very often and very intensely. I for one experience mental pain when I am truly bored, locked in a room for example, and i would much rather suffer the long term consequences of satiating that boredom quickly than endure this mental barrage of endless and uncontrollable thought. But another aspect I want to address is that I, and I assume people with similar mental illnesses, have the ability to think through distractions in the way that you described in this video, making plans, self-reflecting, and remembering important things.

I also think just living with our boredom in certain situations is important for developing a healthy amount of self control. For example, if you're in a class and find yourself bored, its not really appropriate to start browsing your phone. That's disrespectful to the lecturer and most likely irresponsible, since someone had to pay for your seat in the class to hear the lectures. That may seem silly to you, but its a slippery slope. One day you're justifying that behavior in a classroom and eventually you're justifying it during a eulogy. Gonna have to disagree with his whole video. The reason why something productive like homework or taking care of chores at home are boring is because our society is bombarded with things specifically designed to over-stimulate our dopamine system. Our generation changes careers more often than any other generation because of the advice from videos like this. Most people in our generation realize that nothing interests us long-term and there’s a good reason for that. We’re addicts. There’s too many unproductive distractions that excite us and stimulate dopamine in our brain. Regular life hen becomes boring. The best thing you can do is a “dopamine cleanse” and disconnect from your phone/social media/YouTube. We’re essentially junkies feigning for our dopamine fix. Most people aren’t going to make videos saying that though, it’s not profitable.

That being said, in an effort to decrease suffering in the world, I feel obligated to share why I disagree with your assertion that a wandering mind is healthful. Believe it or not, a majority of our thoughts are not our own, they are memories of things we have heard. Quite often they are the projections of other people regarding things that we should be doing or being that they prefer. They usually do not have our best interest or the best interest of the planet at heart. When bored, it is much more of value to conduct insight meditation or better yet self-inquiry. Insight meditation allows us to look at the thoughts as content and dig deep into their root source not within the brain but within our history. It is this rampant creation of a life story that is the problem on the planet at the moment. We need more truth of who we are and self-inquiry can produce that. We are not these stories that in the end fade away but a much bigger truth.

I miss my college years in 2008, before smart phones were mainstream and Facebook was in its infancy.

Often did I used to just go out at night by myself smoking in the parking lot having nothing but my thoughts and me go back and forth and think about my life: past, present, and future.

Nowadays, it's very difficult to have that with a phone in our hands and so much mental stimulation. It's preventing that kind of "self meditation" and I've been feeling the effects for years now 😢

This is the way of the future, and it's gonna get worse and worse in future generations unless a massive 'electronic' revolution happens.

Mind you, I love the fact that information and knowledge is so much more easily attainable now, but there's a price we are all paying for it...

I can't leave the tiny room, I can't open the windows, I can't do yoga or stretching because it's a tiny little room. The first week was fine, but the second week was hell. I had nothing to do and I can't do anything. I didn't have cleaning or housework to do, I can't cook, I can't talk to people, I can't draw. I didn't have a book because it was the peak of COVID and me as an overseas student threw away a lot of things just to fit the most important things in the luggage. I could only look out the window and stared at the tall buildings (can't even see the sky because the hotel is surrounded by skyscrapers). I could type a story but doing that for 15 hours every day tires me out and I would get less creative and more stressed. Life for that week was almost the same as living in solitary confinement. My body starts getting really sluggish, wake up, eat, sleep, wake up, eat, sleep. I was so bored that my body chose to shut off and sleep away the hours. I was lying on the bed lethargic like a chronically ill patient. I even had the thought of making cuts on my skin to bleed so at least it was something new and I could tend to my wounds (or inflict more pain and bleeding). To make the situation more terrifying, just right before this quarantine period, I got off the plane and sat in a large room (with wifi but without charger) from 11am to 9pm just to wait for the COVID test results. I had about 5-6 hours of online surfing but it drains the battery. I was only given a cold sandwich and a bottle of water for the whole 10 hours, so I sat there starved and cold, and I wasn't allowed to move around unless for toilets. This kind of boredom is terrifying and I am glad I don't have to do it again.

Im soon 18, and I still dont have a sim card or data on my phone. I even deleted social media platforms on my phone, but I still go on my laptop, and since  I dont have a place to sit or a desk everywhere, my screen time has reduced significantly. So when I go to places, I usually dont have wifi (maybe if the place has one but it makes me feel guilty of even using it because it is not safe). The point is that: outside of home and school, my phone was practically useless, the number of times I got lost because I needed to attend to place made me learn more about the different buses, taking the time to read street names and especially remember which path I took to come back home. Since, I was gaming less as well because Im a full time student, I feel like I had more time to commit to clubs and contribute more. I know this all sounds nice, but when I ask others to join with me to do some simple activities (boring activities) like playing chess, they laugh at me and be like ''Oh I haven't played it's been so long but sorry I don't have time'' and then proceed to surf on tiktok for an hour kinda in front of me. Now the thing is that Im not against social media, it keeps me updated on news about the world, some influencers actually motivate me and some of the post(such as cat videos) make laugh during a bad day but I feel like you take the time to think less overall about yourself and your ambitions.

Dear Veritasium, Unfortunately, you have coupled “boredom” with a state of mind often called “free association”. As if they are irrevocably joined in tandem. Maybe this was deliberate on your part in order to evoke a conversation and a debate for the purpose of expanding your video reach. There’s nothing inherently immoral about that. I usually thoroughly enjoy your videos that I select to watch. However this one does not make an important & valuable distinction. A state of mind where one a person is deliberately allowing themselves to let their thoughts wonder where they will for a time, can often be a conscious choice and may have nothing at all to do with boredom in anyway. I’m not taking anything away from anyone who is gathered some insights from viewing this video. And I applaud you for inspiring the epiphanies that people have experienced as a result of viewing the video. However, being that I’ve been a “creative“ from childhood and have purposely used quiet time to allow my mind to free associate for the purpose of solving visual and personal real world problems, I believe you have ignored an entire segment of what open and free thinking is truly about. Letting one minds wander is certainly not simply boredom. You may have quoted certain scientific experiments, but your proposed idea in this video is flawed with no actual concrete scientific proof that boredom equals free association & creative thinking. But of course, your videos are all only for entertainment; aren’t they.

I try to practice intentional boredom on a regular basis. Not meditation but actual boredom. It starts with turning off all electronic devices, so no phone or tv or laptop. I have become more creative and less dependent on electronic stimuli as a result. In the autumn of each year I go on a self imposed retreat for anywhere from 2-6 weeks. I have a place deep in the forest up in the mountains they I use for this retreat. Some years I’m alone the entire time and other years I have a friend or two join me. We dont use phones or tv or anything else electronic. We do have some books as well as keep journals and some of us draw. We engage in conversation at length and it’s incredible what happens. We have a big bag that we use to hold slips of paper that we have written topics on. We each write down at least a dozen topics and each day we pull a slip of paper from the bag. This way the topics are random. The topic chosen is the main topic of the day and the conversation ebbs and flows all day. You get incredible insight into what you and your friends believe about certain topics. This annual retreat is wonderful at helping to remember what’s important in life and serves as a kind of reset. I recommend everyone try a version of this and see the benefits for yourself.

It does not make you more altruistic according to the reason you provided. You said people are more likely to donate money to charity or donate blood which practically helps others but the essential reason one does them is to get rid of their boredom, which is a selfish desire.

It is impossible to be selfless unless you see others as a part of yourself through love, empathy, compassion, etc which seems to be selfless but is still technically selfish because now the person sees others as a part of himself thus they still are doing things for themselves.

The reason why it is impossible to be selfless is related to the very nature of desires which guide our actions. In the very core of things, a desire is to move from dissatisfaction to fulfillment. The very reason why someone desires is that they are not satisfied with the present moment as it is. If we were completely fulfilled with life, as if there is nothing left to do, we could just stand in one place and die. Since everything we do comes out from this process of trying to fulfill ourselves, no action can be truly selfless.

I love electronics, been using them throughout my life. Even was a programmer for a time. However, the thought of boredom and it's importance has crossed my mind on several occasions. Games, phones, movies, music, all these forms of entertainment. To what amount of time do they take and to what cost where they to rip away the attention you could've used to ponder your own life and make otherwise meaningful decisions?

I regretfully say, I've spend far too much of my life playing games. They're always there for me, and I've hardly had anything enforcing me to stray away from playing them. I've always felt alone and stand offish, my grades were horrible, and I was always insecure (and still am). However, back throughout my school years. I wanted to be an artist. I drew often over an array of things durring class and during school as a whole. Mind you, I didn't have a phone until I was 17. Once I did get a phone however... that all kinda... stopped. My mind didn't bother to wonder as much any more. Instead, I just spent my time playing some game on my phone instead.

I understand now the importance of boredom, the ability to express your freedom of thought. However... with the abundance of electronics around now a days, it can be hard to NOT use them. This does get me wondering though. If I were stripped of all electronics at a young age, what would I being doing with my life now?...

This is just my opinion, but to me, this argument feels a bit weak. Evidence that there are advantages to being bored doesn't support the idea that doing something else is less productive or will negatively impact you over staying bored. The potential advantages to boredom don't counteract the advantages of engaging in other activities. Boredom doesn't have to be abated by idle, shallow activities. A phone can be used to engage meaningfully with things or people that you care about, which could have a greater benefit over being bored.

When I was a child I was severely bullied, and when I was at home not even getting bullied, just bored, those memories would go through my head and torture me, I know this as ptsd as I have been diagnosed with it, but then I didn’t. I found YouTube when I was 14 and it completely changed my life, my boredom and thinking about how horrible my life was was replaced with thousands of videos like this from hundreds of different people on YouTube, I found love for different activities I never even knew existed! But now I’m in my early 20s, with no more bullies, ptsd is still there but I know how to control it, and I’m still spending literally all of my free time watching YouTube like I have been for the past 8 years. At this point it’s an addiction and I know it, but I don’t know what to do because this has been the only thing I do outside of school and work because I have no real life friends, it’s like I don’t know how to actually live like a human anymore. I’ve also been diagnosed with adhd and I think this may have a hand in it as well. I really need something to pull me away from this and the internet, but nowadays that really seems impossible. I fear that billions of other people have this addiction too, though maybe not as intense, but it still makes me very nervous for our future as a species, boredom really is a good thing when you’re not down on yourself like I was, but we’re trying our hardest to eliminate it. If anybody actually reads this, it means so much to me, this is coming straight from my heart, I really want every single human on this planet to live the greatest life they can.

No. Please only speak for your allistic self. I maintain as constant a state of stimulation as I can, and it makes me waaay more creative than otherwise. It has rekindled my childlike curiosity and creativity, and actively seeking experiences has made me a better person than I used to be, and has helped me to be better equipped with the tools to know myself than before. More information - more stimulus - has helped me grow. I hear a song and now I think "that musical structure caught my ear; I want to analyze it and make music based on new musical ideas". I read a story and think "these narrative devices are beautiful, and having the lexicon to understand what about them is so impactful makes it all the more meaningful when I think about it". Listening to voices of experts and seeking learning helps me grow. Thinking more, and having a broader scope to think about, helps me grow. Boredom is a kind of pain. It is bad. One doesn't need to to grow. One needs curiosity. Boredom is a push. Curiosity is a pull. The pull is what is beneficial.

Hm I Find this interesting albeit incomplete. It frames the avoidance of boredom as purely an individuals choice, without commenting at all on how so many of these things (social media, YouTube, etc) are designed intentionally to draw you in and make you keep using them. How does the external pressure of this attention economy effect this? If we so need boredom to improve ourselves and make things how do you do this in a digital space so designed to let you be anything but? I know the easy answer is just stop, but that doesn't undo the larger systems at work that incentivize you don't. Feels especially important with all the Facebook leaks.

Also I feel like it'd be worth exploring who gets more easy access to boredom, and how we are taught to respond to it.

I have severe ADHD and am a cosmologist that studied the origins of the universe. I'm literally always bored (because of the former) and underwhelmed (because of the latter) by what is happening around me. You could call me an expert on boredom and daydreaming. I also never use my phone to alleviate boredom for two main reasons. First, it bores me. And second, I've gotten so proficient at trying to alleviate my own boredom with my thoughts that I have on many occasions just sat in a room for hours on end doing literally nothing while waiting for something. I am no more bored with that than with any other task.

As an expert on boredom, I can agree with some of the good things pointed out by this video. However, it is worth mentioning that it has some serious drawbacks. While boredom before a task can make you more creative, boredom during a task will definitely make you less creative. Bored people aren't going to put the effort into making the best decision, they are going to make the fastest, easiest decision to get done quickly. As for the altruism, I think that's more a result of introspection making you more considerate and empathetic towards other people. It's not necessarily actual altruism; it might lead to, for example, increased utilitarianism.

Honestly, I had other points for downsides to counter introspection and the rest, but now I'm bored with writing this comment (I wrote the stuff below earlier).

Background fact: ADHD causes a deficiency in neurotransmitters in the brain. The brain requires these neurotransmitters to maintain conscious awareness and will prioritize any action that maintains the minimum threshold. They are generated usually whenever you find something interesting in the task you are focused on. Excess amounts are used to increase your interest in these tasks. Thus, having a severe deficiency would limit your ability to be interested and also, therefore, your ability to stay conscious while performing certain tasks. The brain will automatically force you to switch focus to anything else in the hopes that it will be interesting enough to generate enough neurotransmitters to maintain conscious functionality. This is why people with ADHD can't focus for long on a topic; they are physically incapable and that also forces them to be bored even when they are generally interested in the subject. They also tend to be impulsive as the brain's way of force-injecting some amount of surprise randomness (read: interesting stuff) into life.

I tend to think of "bored" and "boredom" as different things. The first is merely a lack of things to do. It could a result of waiting in line, waiting for food, wait for... probably anything at all. When that happens, my mind has always wandered (although I intentionally pull out my phone in cramped places, when my mind wanders I'm not thinking about my eyes and that can cause all sorts of social issues). Similarly when going on long walks, doing menial tasks, etc. I think that's what this video is explaining.
"Boredom" is a state of complete blah. Where I'm too restless to do nothing, too uncaring to do something (everything seems whatever) and not in the right mind state to even think. It absolutely sucks and has lasted upwards of 2 hours, regardless of what I'm doing, where I am, etc. Even watching TV can't alleviate it and I can't even focus on what I'm watching (or reading if online or with a book). Luckily, I haven't felt this state in years.

I find it interesting the number of people with ADHD commenting on this video about how they handle their boredom. I also have ADHD, and I feel that what drives my divergent thoughts is almost entirely boredom. It's almost as if these thoughts are a way to self treat boredom. For example, when I zone out in conversations its when the conversation no longer holds my interest, but something said earlier or something that happened during my day takes my interest. I don't know how my brain decides what to focus on, but something will come up and I'll focus on that instead. Although there are a lot of negatives to this, like upset friends or family, there is also an equal amount of good. It makes it easier to come up with unique jokes, ideas, and ways to entertain ourselves. I may hyper focus on a video game, but more often than not my brain decides its no longer rewarding enough and I move on to something else, like my next project of home automation. It's this ability to not have our focus entrapped that allows people with ADHD to problem solve so well, even if we may not see the problem entirely through due to boredom. It makes my curiosity wonder how this could potentially open up new ideas into the research of boredom, and whether someone has thought to see how people with different brains deal with and experience boredom.

When I was 14-15 years old. I wanted to reject accepting that I am getting bored. In all the scenarios where I have nothing to do  I’ve started to think about people,society and my observations about life.(I love being an introvert most of the time)  It was like I was making practices about the feelings, situations which I did not come across yet and it helped me a lot. I became  more confident. I have made decisions about certain things in life way before  I even get to those points where I should really be thinking about them. And that made me wiser than most of my friends in some aspects. When someone was struggling something new It wasn’t new for me and I was able to support and share my pre-studied knowledge or the conclusions from my experiences. It developed my ‘narrating self’.  I’ve started to know myself better day by day. I have not just learned to express myself well but in addition, I have learned how to make people understand what I am talking about. Comes down to the confliction between What you assume the people know VS What they really know about the context of your sentences. Anyway I am even more grateful for those days now that I saw this video proving me kinda right.  Sorry for sounding like a guy who is bragging. Just want to point out that boredom can become a fun activity or a relaxing time with yourself. Just being alone with your own thoughts. That way you can express yourself to yourself directly and get to know yourself a lot better.

The common pessimistic interpretation of the experiment at the beginning of the video is that people would avoid boredom even by self-inflecting pain. However, if the goal of life is non-Freudian, not a “Will to Pleasure”, but rather a “will to meaning,” then more experiences and connections with the world give us meaning through pain or pleasure. Imagine I’m locked in a room for three weeks only with the electric shock button and with no memory abilities; touching the button would be the only way for me to experience being alive. Thus, shocking ourselves is to choose to live a life, avoiding pain, and pursuing boredom is not.
At the same time, there is no denying that a brief period of boredom can benefit our brain, allowing our monkey brain to recalibrate rather than riding off the existing dopamine and endorphin-filled path, which distinguishes us from lab mice. Just that the interpretation of the experiment needs to be revised, it’s not wrong to avoid boredom via pain. Most of the things we pursue in life are painful in nature, e.g., love and friendship often lead to tragic endings, rock-climbing is painful, or even careers.

I remember watching it a few years ago and deciding not to look at my phone while waiting for someone or something, but I didn't take into account that I am a very insecure person -- so yeah, as you may have already guessed, It didn't work out for me. I started noticing people’s looks on me more than I should and, consequently, turned out to be a bit paranoid because, by choice, I had no means available to avoid that feeling anymore.

I reckon it was better to just distract myself with the news or something in those situations because the “goal-setting” happened when I was alone, relaxing and/or listening to some music while starring at the ceiling or the view at my window, not waiting in lines. This advice of not using the phone may only be worth taking if your objective is giving the impression of being a rough/smart/humble person or whatever. This image game doesn't matter to me, personally, because I won't ever be seeing those people again in my life.

I've noticed at times that I'm just on my phone or pc too much. To the point where I would rather scroll for hours to find the right youtube video instead of getting up. Those are times where I feel uncomfortable with what I am and what I should and could be doing. My solution:

lie on the floor.

Not joking.

I think about what I have to do, and what events I have planned in the near and far future. And after a good bit of nothing, I feel calmer. I feel a sense to actually do something. Obviously if I'm always laying on the floor the effect gets lessened, but it's a surefire way to just tell my brain, "shut up, you don't need to stare at a screen." No phones, nothing within my reach. Just me and my carpet.

Even thinking about anything than can activate a bit of boredom in me is painful and I know I have to change my job, but there is always this thought in the back of my head telling me that 3 - 5 months in the new job and I will feel the same, so I don't see any point in doing so and changing job is going to cause boredom in me too, of course I can find a job which isn't boring but jobs like that require knowledge and how to learn while being in so devastated state... Seriously, boredom can put you in a very vicious cycle if you don't look at it as it's your enemy and you underestimate it. To support the problem about altruism or just provide my example, I am a bookworm and I constantly read historical novels, fiction, and fanfics. But during the lockdown, it became just so boring to lie on the bed and read the books all day long. So, instead, I started feeling bored and helped my mum do the household chores. Before this simple household chores like washing the dishes or making a table seemed like too much to do and a burden really. But for the first time, I really enjoyed it and paid attention to how my little brother complimented my dish and started trying out new recipes. Well, even though I did not become so much selfless I understood that helping others brings so much joy.

Generally what you're saying is that action and change are good for our lives. When I seek to alleviate boredom, by "distracting myself" with a phone or app or game or whatever, it allows me to take a break from life, which feels really therapeutic for me. I don't know about the rest of you, but I need this alone time to myself, effectively "doing nothing". Life can feel like a pressure chamber sometimes, and maybe I don't want to be creative, altruistic, or plan my life out 24/7 - it feels like I'm "working" on my life in those cases, and "working" can also make me feel exhausted, lethargic, etc. I do enjoy every type of these times, don't get me wrong, but I also enjoy "not being bored".

You've described my condition, but sadly with none of the benefits. As someone who's had ADHD, my mind drifts off all the time. I love daydreaming, it's my favorite past time. There are times where I'll be watching a video or reading an article, and I have to pause & start applying whatever new interesting concept I've discovered into my mind.

It doesn't always have to be highly intellectual either, it can even be shallow sometimes – like if I see a cute outfit, I have to stop and imagine a storyline where I'm wearing it, or I see a cute guy in a photo and he becomes a stranger I imagine meeting. I do a lot of "autobiographical planning", but I can't seem to transition this into my actual life. I prefer my headspace over reality. I have a really good imagination, so much so that I could zone out completely and have been repeatedly admonished for it.

My mind palace is where I go to feel safe, build awesome worlds, and live my life as I see fit – especially bc I'm so paralyzed by fear in real life. I feel most relaxed where I can feel in control. I've spent so many hours of my life staring into space or staring at a wall. I also get annoyed when people interrupt my thoughts to talk to me. I have to focus on what they're saying, and often times I tune them out, which gets me in trouble. Idk why I'm like this. It used to be fun, but it's become debilitating, bc I'm not productive and my life is so stagnant as a result.

Boredom is just another way of saying you're having an existential crisis. Yet if you lose yourself in your thoughts as you are bored, that boredom transforms into enlightenment. Having the time to stop and think about things allows you to observe things you would normally just ignore. It is a critical part of humility, the feeling that makes you more inclined to tolerate situations, but it is also a critical part of fear.

After all, people don't like having an existential crisis. Observing the things you are comfortable with are fine, but also thoughts of things that make you uncomfortable spring up. If your anxiety builds, doubts will spawn from this eventually leading to a sense of urgency and panic. I'd say it's natural to avoid that fear when it's uncalled for, which is why distracting yourself from boredom by actively doing something else is common. Though if you can just get comfortable, being bored is an opportunity to find something you didn't notice before, and admire just how cool it is.

Boredom is wonderful, because before when I would mindlessly scroll and feel sick for hours laying down with a device on social media.
I have now 'boredom' due to my continuous ritual of studying 9-14 hours a day for ONLY the past 3 days! Today I reached 14, and I have now NOT only found fulfillment and drive to help me keep going TOWARD my goal, but ALSO the feeling of comfort THROUGH boredom!
This is because the simple tacking of time put into DEDICATED time, has resulted in continuous daily goals achieved that I set at the end of each day, for the next. This feeling during and after work makes me feel AMAZING, and it ISN'T a superpower!
You just simply have to think for yourself without doing things on instinct, because no matter HOW MUCH you know, your thoughts and instinct are outdated, so UPDATE IT!! I'm not even thinking of the final goal anymore, or have any motivation to keep going, I just turned this idea of working hard and smart into a habit, and thus, I feel the same as any other habit, like going on the phone to watch YouTube or eating all the food on your plate (if the food is delicious). Think about it this way, do you wake up EVERY SINGLE DAY motivated to watch YouTube? NO. You online get motivated to start something new or rarely experienced! So, that ultimately means that over time, any goal that you work towards (as long as the work is the same for a long period of time) becomes as easy as mind scrolling on YouTube! I'm even getting urges now to procrastinating from SLEEPING and work instead because I feel as though waiting for sleeping is more boring.
THUUUUUUUSSS, Making habits to change your life is not only possible, but it's also doable.
SO HURRY UP AND BE CONSISTENT AFTER STARTING!!

I almost never get bored. I've come to realize that boredom is simply a lack of opportunity to investigate. It's what happens when you are stuck in the backseat on long car rides, or in a classroom for a subject you don't care about. Or even actively doing the same task over and over (eg. long, straight walks) without interruption.

As long as you keep investigating things, you never become bored. Kids often get bored because they get restrained (often by adults) into being in one place and cannot go investigate/discover things. Too much of this and people lose the desire to investigate and the mind becomes dull in order to ignore and cope with the boredom.

It's arguably not just a state of being underwhelmed or a state that tells us we should be doing something ,more so a state of unease at having to deal with ourselves and our demons. People think being productive is a pro - even this videos perspective is about getting things done - but being overproductive can be a sign of depression. People think doing is important when they're literally unable to sit in a room alone. A cat does not have this problem and it's not a coincidence that it's not capable of forming such a complex ego with all of its psychological problems. Boredom is the state that tells us we feel something bad about ourselves - that .aybe something about us needs caring for. Escaping boredom is how any addiction starts and every addict will tell you there is something wrong with them, not that they need to be more creative.

Thanks for this thought-provoking video.  A couple of random thoughts that sprang to mind while watching: 1. While I fully agree that boredom CAN be good for you, I think it is a two-edged sword (remember the old adage "The devil makes work for idle hands"): so, while scrolling through Twitter in every spare moment might be making you less inventive/creative, it could also be helping to keep you out of prison!   2. I think your description/definition of boredom as (to paraphrase) being unrelated to not having things to do but rather about not actually wanting/feeling motivated to do anything in particular, is spot-on.  In fact, I  think it might even not be going too far to consider boredom a mild form of depression.   3.  Maybe one reason to avoid boredom via even the most meaningless, frivolous activities is that we know from experience that, when mentally unoccupied, we are likely to dwell excessively on negative, rather than positive, thoughts or recall negative, rather than positive, experiences.  There's another old adage: "Where you plant flowers, flowers will grow; where you plant weeds, weeds will grow; and where you plant nothing, weeds will still grow".  Having nothing to think about is, for most of us, like planting nothing: negative thoughts, like weeds, will grow...

Very interesting video as always. I had heard of these studies and they sound like they are creating a false dichotomy. There is an assumption that for thoughts to come to be examined you need these moments of boredom, when in fact creativity studies show that similar results as the ones mentioned in the video can be observed when the subject is involved in certain activities such as running, taking a shower or/and when they are facing "inspirational experience" - watching a painting, looking at the sky, listening to someone speak....
For example if I'm cleaning dishes while listening to a podcast about philosophy, those actions can actually induce the examination of many deep thoughts. More so than sheer boredom.
I honestly don't think we should be chacing boredom but we certainly should be chasing meaningful activities as opposed to ones that stop us from thinking through important things in our lives.

I know this is old, but I still wanna give some input.
I am not a normal case so this is useless info anyways, but in my case, I spend too much time in introspective thinking and just doing nothing.
I see no sense in anything, nothing is worth anything or has any objective point. That is simply the truth of the universe. Things only have the subjective worth we assign to them personally. But due to a lot of psychological problems and me being a very logical thinker, I completely lost that perspective and cannot force myself to assign worth to anything. It just doesn't happen, no matter how much I try. So for a couple of years now, my life consisted of a constant struggle to kill time because the second I am not doing anything, I get caught in my thoughts, which can be very self destructive. But at the same time, I end up just sitting around bored, imagining things and thinking about stuff for at least an hour or two every single day because I also keep telling myself that doing things, like, anything, even if it is something I would have fun doing, is not worth the effort. Simply because nothing is worth anything.
As I said I cannot get rid of that truth stuck in the forefront of my mind and as such I cannot force myself to do anything that requires proactive action at all most of the time, since the more effort something takes, the more wasted effort it is. Simply because all effort is inherintely wasted when you understand that nothing truly matters.
So my point is, boredom is not good for me. All my introspection and me just being alone in my thoughts too much made me develope such a strong apathy for everything in life that I'd really rather just die because there is nothing interesting anymore. I have friends, I have hobbies, but I really just suffer through everyday life and did not have a single happy day for as long as I can remember since these problems started at an early age, triggered by a lot of physical and mental abuse from my parents which made me question my worth and the general worth and meaning of anything really. The logical conclusion was that, my parents being aggressive people and me being in the way of their outbursts, of course I held no relative value or worth in those situations so they would do to me whatever they wanted. It makes sense. Everything is like that, people claim moral highgrounds by trying to establish things that have universal worth and things that we should condemn, but in reality all of that is nonsense.
Nothing has any worth. Nothing matters. And I can not find the motivation to do anything because of that. Not even to finally kill myself. I can not be bothered to walk to the train station and just jump infront of the next train. That would be too much wasted effort for my unmotivated brain.

I am hardly ever bored.
I spend more time with my thoughts than with my smartphone.
I spend time listening to myself, time to slow down my thoughts.
The realm of my thoughts is bigger than what my eyes see.
It is also so much more peaceful than the outside world.

Strangely enough it opens you up more to gaze at the world around,
More open minded to the people around

When there is a moment you have nothing to do, wait or so
Look around and see the beauty in the many things around

To call it boredom is maybe the wrong name to it.
I see people avoiding it in order to avoid themselves, not to avoid boredom.
The smartphone is a way to escape themselves,
To escape this voice inside.

I have unknowingly been making myself the most creative altruistic person imaginable.

In recent years the population of rural China keeps shrinking very quickly, but still my parents and me went back to their home village during every lunar new year holiday. There were no longer many relatives and friends in the village because many of them moved away or just passed away, and the new years are far from being lively as it was before. So during these new years I spent several days without television, because I don't watch TV anyway, without mobile internet because the 4G signal was bad among the hills even it is in China, I just went for a walk in the mountains or simply put a chair at the doorstep of the old house and bathed in the winter sun light, and amuse myself with nothing except my own thoughts and imagination and the landscape. It might seems very boring, but I felt quit OK once I got used to it.

One theory about ADHD is that people with ADHD have a chronically under-stimulated brain, thus they are constantly looking for stimulation.

In my experience with ADHD, I think I do need some sort of baseline stimulus in order to function. The problem is when that stimulus satisfies me completely and I don't want to do anything else. I find that there's a sweet spot; a small amount of stimulus that allows me to focus. Any less and my thoughts will be incoherent and jumbled. Any more and it becomes a distraction. It's a balance. A fidget toy is very effective, but music works too, especially instrumental.

With ADHD, a lack of stimulation is its own distraction.

A lot of good info, but unfortunately one-sided. Boredom can lead to numerous detrimental outcomes as well, like an increase in unhealthy consumption, depression, increased biased and discriminatory actions, unsafe driving, pathological gambling, etc. Not saying he's wrong, just that it's not as simple as "Well, actually, boredom is good."

This also only really looks at situative boredom, which is often beyond our control and very short-term, so I don't think his analysis applies as strongly as he seems to think it does. Chronic boredom is a larger issue, and his suggestions at the end actually make more sense for those who experience this type of boredom.

Experienced meditators myself included usually claim to never get bored, because, speaking for myself, vipassana or mindfulness meditation in the Buddhist tradition trains you to 'see" every experience - sensation, feeling, mood, thought, mental image, idea, symbol, taste, gesture, step -  as complex, multifaceted, rich and therefore at least partially unexplored, new, fresh.  I agree with the definition given, that boredom is feeling unsatisfied with the perceived options available - that boredom is a failure of imagination, and an inability to see past our own perceptions, what some Buddhists refer to as emptiness, that perception is NOT reality (sensation is as close as we get) - but boredom does not have to be a necessary step on the way to daydreaming, altruistic action, biographical planning or any more practical behavior at all.  I guess my message here is that you can do good without being bored, and in fact, with some training, you never have to be bored at all.

As someone with ADHD, I get bored super easily, and it's really easy for me to get trapped in a boredom cycle where I just end up napping or dozing because nothing I can think of is worth doing. To keep myself from getting bored while doing literally anything, I need at least two stimuli; I sew while watching TV or listening to a podcast, I have instrumental music on while I do homework, etc. Heck, I wrote this comment while watching this video! I certainly agree with the idea that being 'bored' is good, but I would argue the creativity shown while avoiding boredom is really just the same thing as doing anything else to avoid it, it's just not electronic/physical, so it's Better, somehow

It would be really interesting to see, or write, a study on boredom, and my current field of work. I work on CNC machines, often times with long run times. This work consists of mostly boring repetitive tasks, sprinkled with rare high attention, high downside, intelligence tasks. When there is work to be done, if everything is going well, it is boring work, doing the same thing over and over again. Then, you have hours to wait sometimes until the next machine needs attention. I have recently experienced 11 hour work days where there was a total of 1 hour of boring work to be done scattered throughout the day, and the rest was spent waiting. It takes a very good data plan to be able to entertain yourself with a phone for that much time, and even if you do - that gets boring too.

Of the people working in this field that I know, most of them spend their off time doing exactly what they want most in life. They spend hours and hours talking out their life plans with each other. When it comes to being creative, if they aren't creative outside of work, they sure are at work. You have never seen how creative a group can be when given 6 hours of boredom, gloves, scissors, and a few paint pens. The pranks can be legendary, and anything can be exciting.

Thinking to myself and being bored are two different things to me. For years, I've gone on walks or bike rides to be with my thoughts. I usually drive in silence too.

Listening to music or podcasts or whatever people do whenever they drive or walk from the parking lot to the office is overwhelming to me if I try to do that, especially if I feel the need to have something new to listen to all the time.

Boredom is a different feeling, which usually happens when I've exhausted my thoughts or if I know that what I'm doing or waiting on is not accomplishing anything, or if I'm sitting at home with nothing planned. It's a sensation unto itself, not just the state of thinking to myself for an extended period of time.

This is an incredible finding! Boredom is the neutral ground of the mind, from the two polar opposites of total lack of motivation and creativity vs high energy hyper productive. Our black and white way of thinking demands more stimulations to fed to either opposites, but when no action is taken to further stimulate those polarized thoughts- like a pendulum, with a little patient, time, and lots of effort, the mind will restores it equilibrium, the middle, that's where true understanding arise, out of both opposites. The saying "happy median" has deeper psychologically meaning.

This is an amazing video. In so many cases, we all operate under the underlying notion that more is better. That stimulus is productive inherently, and that time not spent is simply time wasted. What studies and insights like this remind us is that happiness, productivity, purpose... life itself, doesn't really operate that way. Sometimes stopping is the right choice. Saying no. Going backwards. Being bored. Doing less. Maybe next time we think about what we should do next, we should allow ourselves to just experience the absence and explore it , and in doing so - potentiate our existence.

The other reason we shouldn't always seek stimulation is because of dopamine desensitisation. By flooding the brain constantly with stimulus from your phone, you reduce your response to dopamine - the neurotransmitter that lets you experience anticipation, excitement and arousal. If you do that all the time, you become less responsive - which leads to your potential to be bored and unresponsive being even greater. In short, most of us are raging dopamine addicts and it's making life less interesting. We need downtime to replenish and recalibrate.

From my experience, I think you only hit one aspect of the usefulness of boredom. I think another major benefit of recurring boredom is that it maintains your idea of what boredom is. If you stay entertained/boredom-free all the time, then your mind starts to get more and more sensitive to boredom. If you go far enough down that rabbit hole, certain forms of entertainment also start to seem boring. So you start watching videos at double speed, or you start having a podcast on while playing a video game, etc. At the same time, you can move your threshold for boredom far enough that even useful actions like doing your job at work or completing your homework can seem unbearably boring, which can lead to you being more distracted and less productive. You, in a sense, develop your own form of ADD. I honestly wish I would have come to that realization a long time ago, because walking back my aversion to boredom is a very irritable process, and since I feel both tired and annoyed, it's very hard to concentrate on important tasks while I'm resetting my boredom threshold. I consistently tell myself that I'm going to be more productive, but inevitably find myself fidgeting or doing seemingly ANYTHING other than what I want to be doing. Because this seems so similar to ADD, I'm starting to wonder if it's over-entertainment that has helped lead to so many kids getting diagnosed with a learning disorder these days. Just a guess, obviously.

Does anyone meditate? Meditation is sitting alone, quietly, eyes closed is an option. Generally the idea is to concentrate on the one mundane thing, something like one's breathing or the ticking of a nearby clock. Veritasium is like human yoda

Yesterday, I decided to get a massage in the wealthier part of town. Afterwards, I took a little stroll around the city and came across a little street corner with a bench nearby.


I took a seat with no distractions and decided I felt like dancing. So, I got up to dance. Right there. On the corner. For no reason other than self pleasure and amusement. I could be on my phone staring blankly into a screen like everyone else around or I could entertain myself with good music and spontaneous dance. A lot more fun then talking on the phone, texting or jumping on social media. Feels more natural, too. Really, not much different than when I was kid dancing freely without a care in the world, especially out in nature.


As I'm dancing, I notice people were slowing down in their cars, watching, pointing, smiling from ear to ear. People who were walking by would give me the nod, a fist pound or hi-five. People from literally a block away would make their way over to me and engage in conversation, complimenting my dance moves and genuinely finding it difficult to leave my company. Some would stop, watch and tell me personally they enjoyed my dancing. And all I could think was, "If only they knew how much more fun I'm having DOING it, then they are WATCHING it." Being a spectator of life is no where near as pleasurable as living life.


Those who inquired, I was trying to let people know that it's okay to just be yourself. EVERYBODY dances in the privacy of their own home. EVERYBODY sings in the shower. So why do so few of us do it in public? We're self-conscious. We're so uncomfortable being in our own skin we're afraid of other peoples opinions about us. We're bombarded with messages of what we THINK we're supposed to do or who society says where supposed to be. We're encouraged to be everything and everyone else but our true authentic self.


The reason why so many people got such pleasure and joy out of me dancing in public is because, deep down in their heart, I'm only doing what they secretly wish they could do. What they lack the courage to do. And you would think, with all the money, wealth, material possesions and the latest gadgets and gizmos these wealthy people have, THEY would be out there dancing EVERY DAMN DAY! I mean, you have all the material comforts money can buy. Why AREN'T they dancing and enjoying life?

This video is greatly misinterpreted by a lot of people. Boredom in essence is bad for your mental health, therefore when you are bored your mind automatically looks for ways to alleviate the feeling, hence the creativity aspect of it. If you purposefully let yourself be bored for extended periods of time during the day, this may lead to depression and lethargy.

Boredom as a whole is not good for you. The part which is good for your creativity specifically is the lack of distractions and the ability for your mind to focus and come up with ideas.

I think what this video is trying to say is, don't let yourself be bored, but rather choose your distractions carefully. Instead of passively observing things on instagram and facebook, actively use your thoughts to create ideas. Both alleviate the feeling of boredom but one is more beneficial than the other in the long run.

I guess I don’t understand how/why being bored is better than doing any of the things that are creative, rewarding in boredom’s place -things that bring me joy. Boredom is the threat, the motivation for doing rewarding things. If I’m bored it’s because I need to do something Or nothing In a more graceful way. That guy who said his phone actually keeps him from being bored was a liar. There was that moment of hesitation where he was thinking of telling the truth but he decided to say "yeah it actually does", probably because he doesn't want to face the reality that mindlessly browsing Facebook doesn't give any actual tangible satisfaction. I don't think there's anything wrong with doing that, but I do think that pretending it's somehow satisfying is really unhealthy, because there's another thing that boredom keeps us from doing: constantly occupying our mind with stuff that doesn't matter.

I found myself feeling much better mentally when I quit worrying so much about checking random crap on my phone. "Oh no, it's been 5 minutes since I last looked at my phone and checked a comment I made on Reddit for a reply. Better pull it out and check one more time. Oh, no comments to my question yet. I'll check later." Only to check it again 5 minutes later. All of these interactions with social media just creates a vicious cycle of constant occupation of your mind. It becomes VERY mentally draining and extremely exhaustive to constantly occupy your mind with wanting to check random crap.

I'm not saying social media is bad, or other forms of entertainment is bad. I'm just saying that these things need to be done in moderation. If you normally check 5 or 6 websites for updates, all throughout the day, maybe try not checking them at all one day and see how that makes you feel later.

?  I think there is an important distinction being missed here.  It sounds like what is being called "bored" here in this video is having a relaxed / clear state of mind, something akin to either induced mind wandering or otherwise. I guess you could try to convert the latter into the former, but there is still that "willful" part.  In the former, you're doing it by choice.  In the latter, it's forced upon you.

The word choice is the fundamental flaw with this video. Boredom creates a need for creativity, but whether or not someone utilizes the moment to be creative is up to them. Being alone in a quiet room with only your thoughts is not boredom but often contemplation. Many people lack the reasoning to contemplate, so they instead are bored. Some of these people will be creative and find a way out of the boredom (i.e. flicking pencils into the ceiling tiles), yet others will remain bored until someone else's creativity helps them (the buzzer in your scenario). Boredom itself is not creativity, but a catalyst for creative minds. Contemplative minds tend to never be bored, as unless currently entertained they are often already resuming their contemplative efforts. Do you think Socrates started asking questions because he was bored? No, he was asking questions even before he started asking them verbally. His life was spent thinking.

A while ago I decided not to use my smartphone at all for a week. Instead I used an oldschool Nokia phone to make calls etc. I had that unpleasant feeling of boredom very often, every day in the 30 min long bus transportation to college, in my algebra class, when I was eating I didn't entertain myself by watching YouTube, I was bored when I was in the toilet... Sometimes I couldn't stand it, and for example, I would grab a shampoo next of me and read the ingredients while I was doing my thing in the toilet, or I played Snake on my Nokia phone in the bus, but I was generally more observant of my enviroment, which is a plus.
But yeah, this video is so true. I play the piano as a hobbie, and that week without my phone I had more ideas of melodies I could make, it felt less boring to learn new stuff. Our phones and social media are trying hard to keep us entertained on our News Feed, by throwing to us countless new and useless information that our lazy brains love. One day I met a friend, she was walking and also scrolling on her phone. "Why do you do that?" I asked. "Walking is boring" she replied, and I didn't like it. Our world is beautiful! If you don't like seeing what's going on around you while you are WALKING, then what?! That screen isn't your life... "And if I was scrolling on my phone too, like you did, we would pass each other without even noticing and say a single 'hi'. Isn't that weird?". She didn't anwser.
Lastly, that particular week I was less lazy in general. I didn't have the option to watch "just one" YouTube video before getting out of bed. I couldn't sleep but I was bored. So, to kill my boredom I could either let my mind wander in thoughts and daydream, or get up and start my day routine earlier, or read a book. All of these options are surely better for your mind than watching an episode of Big Bang Theory or watch stories on Instagram.
These are my thoughts. I totally agree with the video. Our brains are prisoners of that fast life. I don't say that life was better before the Internet 'cause Internet and new technology etc are undoubtedly brilliant inventions! We just need to learn how to use this powerful tool wisely and give our amazing minds some space to shine. Thanks for your time.

I'm surprised and a bit disappointed that he didn't mention mindfulness or meditation at all. Yes, stopping to think is definitely useful, but often when we do, we get lost in negative narratives and thought loops. Having a moment of mindfulness when in line, or at a stop light can be very useful as well. You can learn to see your thoughts and observer the patterns, and connect more with your environment to feel more connected to everything around you. It promotes a state of calm and peace and allows you to process difficult emotions more easily, and it helps generate compassion for others. I'd say both thinking and meditation are useful, and it's good to choose which one to do in each moment. If you're thinking and you find that the thoughts aren't serving you, you can stop and focus on your body sensations, the sounds and smells around you, and observe the thought trains passing by rather than getting pulled along by them.

I don't know - somehow this video fails to connect with my life experience (I'm now 59).
For one, should I pull out my phone (as opposed to my Kindle), it tends to be to read some more paragraphs in a story I'm currently in. Which, in my experience, often triggers thought about any topic you can think of, which per this video would be the function of boredom, so it seems I don't actually lose something. In fact, this way, I might get someone else's perspective on something I wouldn't have otherwise ever pondered.
Whereas when I'm really bored (which means my trusty "think about a programming problem or try to explain some aspect of the world around me to an imaginary person completely unfamiliar with the concepts involved" somehow didn't work), my thoughts tend to circle around chasing each other, almost giving me physical pain, and no particularly interesting ideas or decisions result.
It may be that what we do with boredom is not as universal as the video makes it out to be.

There was a great short story by Asimov, I think it was called 'Thinking Time'. In it, an author wishes for his life to be made more convenient and efficient, thinking it would give him more time to write. At first, he is overjoyed to never have to wait at a long line, to always have a cashier open up or bus pull in just as he's arriving. However, he gradually comes to the realization that without the boredom and frustration of waiting and doing nothing, the ideas and passions he fed into his writing failed to appear, and he eventually walks away from his craft.

Conclusion spiraled out of control. Unless one can prove that people are less altruistic today with the presence of smartphones than then were prior their prevalence, I'd say that the conclusion is more based on fear and/or nostalgia for a constantly shifting "golden days" that seems to affect most as they get older.

Did people standing in line in the past let themselves be "alone with their thoughts" or find other things to concentrate on (e.g., products on display in the checkout line designed to get your attention for last-minute purchases, the person taking too long in front of you, a strange outfit someone is wearing, your immediate plans when you get home). The outcome of being alone with one's thoughts, I hypothesize to be contingent upon the positivity of one internal dialogue (you can also spend that time waiting in line focusing on a particular slight/insult you endured recently and playing out the many levels of its offense and the many aggressive ways in which you could have responded).

What's interesting about the "phone book" experiment is that the participants were given a task which, even though it was a mundane one, gives a sense purpose. This task is something to help them feel busy and someone purposeful (don't forget that knowledge that one is involved in an experiment is also bound to affect one's sense of purpose...though to what degree I can't say).

I personally have found that I my imagination hits me full force when I'm tasked with mundane activities (washing the dishes, folding clothes, etc.). I don't think people usually feel socially "at ease" while waiting in lines, so the hidden factor may be social anxiety as opposed to boredom that makes people automatically pull out their phones...the awkwardness of close-encountered silent social order that occurs in elevators and waiting rooms.

You can pull out your phone during class or you can stare out the window. In both cases you are missing what the instructor presenting but I suppose in the latter case, according to the conclusion, you'll leave the class more creatively primed? Some of the individual observations/studies in this video were interesting but I think it might be a bit early to bring any practical cohesion to them.

I used to be addicted to video games, and much of why it was so hard to quit was because I didn’t know what to do with myself besides playing video games. Nothing seemed as satisfying, and everything seemed like a waste of time, that it would be boring. As I got older I was able to recognize what my addiction to video games was doing to my mind, and once I quit, I fully realized the harm being addicted to them had done to me. My interests in all other things have faded, and it’s taking a while to get them back. If I let myself sit and be bored once in a while, I feel that I would have developed my other interests more and would have a clearer life-trajectory than I do now.

So, I’m not saying that video games overall are bad, just that being addicted to them is bad for your mental health, short term and long term.

Boredom is impossible... We are doing something non-enjoyable using a low capacity of our mental capacity. So our minds start to wander...We begin to think creatively, about our past, about our future, about others. Now I am not bored anymore. I've seen a few of these why we need boredom, or the benefits of boredom videos, and I am giving them a thumbs down. I don't think we can ever truly be "bored", as described above. We can, however, be doing something non-enjoyable that takes a large amount of mental capacity, then our mind wandering is called a distraction. Take my daughter doing her school work for example. I myself have a relatively "boring" job that generally doesn't take a large mental capacity. But I am rarely "bored" at work. Instead I watch insightful YouTube videos, I think about my past, present, and future, etc.  It would be better to say that access to information and social media are stifling our creative processes. Otherwise, it seems like all these "boredom" videos are suggesting we need to dedicate an amount of time to staring at a blank wall.

I watched this a few days ago and was actively conscious of my actions within class due to your example. Though I mostly agree with your presentation of this video, I came to realize that when I became less interested in what the professor had to say (usually from either rambling or material I already knew) I went back to my laptop to get more things accomplished. In some sense, in that moment I realized the value of the presentation and information provided was far less than the value of conserving time by responding to important emails, preparing the homework problems I would have to do later, and other tasks that I was required to do at some point in time. After realizing this, I found that a lot of time I spent on my phone or laptop was in similar spirit of conserving time by doing small bits of tasks throughout the day. Of course, there were some instances of purely relieving boredom by watching/reading things on social media and YouTube, but the majority of time was spent doing productive or semi-productive tasks.

Videos and articles with themes similar to this do have very relevant and important points to be made, but this comment is serving as a reminder that not all value compromises that result in using technology are inherently bad. So, instead of just tallying or recording how much time you are spending with technology, analyze what occasions are being used for productive purposes and what occasions are being used for simply passing the time.

The concept in this video is why recently I have taken to a new strategy in my personal work space. In the past if I couldn't get anything done I would go do something else and come back to it or intend to come back to it. So now I adopted a strategy of laying a pad of paper, pencil and any relevant measuring devices in front of me. If it's so beneficial, why does it feel so negative? If it were beneficial, seems like it would be evolutionarily advantageous to enjoy a lack of stimulation, but it's generally not.

Is it because our bodies are essentially still the same as our stone age ancestors who lived more day-by-day and wouldn't benefit as much from introspection and long-term planning? In those days, not taking advantage of immediate "downtime" could mean the difference between eating or going hungry that day.

Modern selection pressures may cause humans to develop an affinity for this downtime. Or perhaps we already do find it just positive enough to pursue it as much as necessary -- boredom isn't generally "agonizing", and it does provide legitimate pleasure at the moment you do have an epiphany about your own life. However, with the advent of smartphones and other modern "distractions", humanity is now exposed to these new temptations and will have to go through a re-calibration to favor the minority of long-term planners while also balancing the need to still be connected and gain new information.

So, I guess what I'm trying to say is my guess as to why it feels negative, despite assuming you are right that always being able to cure your boredom with technology will be detrimental to many people's lives: Competitive pressures will favor people who can appropriately balance long term planning and short term satisfaction. Boredom will feel less "bad" to future humans after the re-calibration of our species's reward system in the face of distracting modern and post-modern society. It feels bad now because we evolved in a completely different environment, where downtime was deadly. Boredom may eventually be eliminated from the gene pool as a negative feeling when our descendants perfect the optimization of their time to out-compete those who don't carve out times for introspection in a world where boredom becomes a choice.

This subject of boredom is one that I have reflected on many times over the years for two reasons: 1) I am a teacher of teenagers who are constantly excusing their lack of interest and involvement to being bored. 2) I don't ever seem to be bored, because I turn all "down time" into an opportunity to push unfinished reflections forward. For these two reasons, when I have a student say to me that he or she is bored, I say to the whole class the following: "Bored is not a circumstance, but a state of mind. Therefore, you should not say 'I am bored', but rather 'I am boring'". I go on to explain that I can and have stood in lines with perfect strangers for more than an hour and not been bored. I can talk to the strangers; I can think about being on the beach or being in the mountains; I can write poetry and try to memorize it so that I can write it down later; I can pray for people; I can plan what I need to do next: I can look for something that raises my curiosity and wonder (an insect crawling on the floor, a refraction of light through the window, an echo or sound resonance in the acoustical space, the rate and pleasantness of service at the front of the line). It takes mental effort and practice to learn not to be boring, but the results for future circumstances is valuable.

I’m assuming the thought process of being bored is something like this

> You’ve got nothing interesting or entertaining to do
> You think for a bit; maybe entertain with your thoughts, come up of ways to become excited
> You think a bit further about more meaningful work you could be doing

At least that’s how I think it happens; a period of self reflection where you wonder what to do to get yourself at least engaged in something


Boredom seems to invoke certain types of ideas that I wouldn’t have if I hadn’t had time to stop and think.

For instance, figuring out how a device works, or certain terminologies, or properties of objects.

For these ideas having a phone is pretty friendly since figuring out how something works is better researched than thought up if you have no idea what’s what.

I could also end up daydreaming. Or thinking up concepts for projects I do. Those ideas unfortunately tend to frustrate me in hindsight; most notably how unoriginal they usually are. That’s something I’ve yet to stray away from (accepting that being unoriginal can still be creative), but I still see merit to strive for it, making it an unpleasant experience.

But more often I’d just blank out, which is actually pretty comfortable. This one’s a strange one, hard to describe with words, other than with “you just do”


There are times where I did go deeper with the thinking about others part or being productive, but usually I never found that fulfilling at all unless it felt instantly satisfying. As an example, I tried running once but felt too much effort and although productive, wasn’t worth it.

Relaxation and thinking isn't necessarily equal to boredom, it depends on what you're thinking about. When I'm relaxing and thinking, unless I'm trying to sleep, I'll be exploring ideas and solving problems in my mind. This is why it's so difficult to stay bored, at least for me, because my brain will just find some internal stimuli. I'd say that reaching for internal thought isn't much different from reaching for your phone, and each of those activities can be useful in a different way.

True boredom for me is when I'm forced to focus on something that isn't very stimulating, like if I'd have to solve 1000 math problems that were all trivial like "3 + 5 x 8". Then I'd have no place to find anything interesting, not in the activity I'm doing or even in my own mind. Relaxation is more stimulating than trivial activities.

I want many things in life:

I want to work (38h a week over 4 days - working in healthcare, helping people and teamwork with collegues)
I want to raise a kids and have a family (currently one 8 month old).
To do that, I bought a house and need to dopart of the chores and I do most of the cooking.

Besides that I have hobbies and skills I want to invest time into:
Learning Japanese, learning 3D modelling, video editing, writing/typing books and stories, drawing on paper, reading books.
On top of that I enjoy keeping up with news, and i watch a lot of infotainment on youtube.
Oh - and I also game quite a bit; since I am also into PC tech - and with a great PC comes great possibilities.

Especially after the birth of my son, there are just not enough hours in the day to do all that i want. At some point I reflected on it and realized I really need to prioritize the things and skills I really want to spend my time on. Whenever I dont feel like doing the current activity, I have a list of other things to switch to. Never bored.

Is there no time to reflect on life? Nonesense. You dont need your full attention for a lot of household chores, and commuting to and from work leaves enough time to reflect on a lot of things.

Your phone is your enemy though! Whats the benefit of browing on facebook or instagram? You keep up to date on things people want to share, but not what they truly are working on.
In the end you dont really do anything - you dont grow, you dont learn, you dont accomplish. My phone has become a tool of communication, a google search tool, my calender, my email, etc. I hardly ever browse social media, unless I want to post something anymore.

I am really glad you made this video, I used to have to drive my grandmother to her doctor appointments so I would frequently spend 10-60 minutes in waiting rooms waiting for her. I always thought to myself that "being bored is okay" and I would use that time to unwind. Some waiting rooms had a TV but usually it was just me alone with my thoughts. I don't have mobile data on my phone so on the rare occasion that I pulled it out I found myself sending texts to people that I hadn't thought about in a while. I typically wouldn't get a response back before my grandmother was finished but later when I did get a reply I was able to have meaningful conversations that I might not have had otherwise. I am interested to see whether people think that my sending of the initial text is the proverbial shock to avoid boredom or a creative result of me taking time to be alone with my thoughts.
