Scott Adams said it something like this: Boredom and creativity go together like salt and french fries, the more you have of one, the easier it is to enjoy the other. That's stuck with me for years, and I've always thought he was right about it.

Think of your body as a kind of space ship.  What we think of boredom, is really the soft humming and whirring of the machinery that works in the background.  Most people have too much noise in their conscious mind to stop and listen to the subtle sounds of our inner workings.  It is a skill that requires practice to turn down the volume in the cortex and just listen to the subconscious.  The subconscious mind is where all of our programs are embedded into memory.  When you allow yourself to access the subconscious part of your mind, you have the ability to make adjustments to that programming.  And in turn, that programming can have an effect on how the hardware of your body functions.  Think about it.  You will have so much more power over your own being if you do.  :)

The thing is that when I am bored I grab my phone because my boredom makes me think about stuff that I want to know and the phone is the answer to those questions.

My point is: what is boredom and why should we stay in that state of mind? For how long? If I am bored and I get creative or start wondering about life and want to answer the questions that might arise because of my boredom, should I not answer them and stay bored? I mean, I want to get out of boredom as quick as I can, and engage in something interesting. Boredom serves me no purpose, but rather I would like to be constantly engaged in something that I enjoy. Thinking about life and reflecting on my current situation and where I stand is engaging and interesting, so I wouldn't classify it a byproduct of "boredom".

This video is an insufferable mix of "today's youth is going to ruin", and "this one simple trick is all it takes to become a great person!".

I don't look at my phone much at all, I don't stay connected constantly filling my attention with my phone. But I'm not magically a better person, nor are those around me who do use their phones worse. Take away the pretty words and have a genuine "bored think" about what's actually being presented here. What do you think the millions of general populous that never grew up without smartphones, who were indeed "bored" at many points of time? Were they a paragon of virtue who worked constantly towards life goals? Or uh, maybe they were exactly the damn same as every other generation since the dawn of humanity.

And if your answer to the above is legitimately "yes the bored people from the past were better human beings", then slap yourself and read some history. Because if humanity has at least one constant, it's people crying about how the current generation is being ruined has been happening for millennia. Educate yourself on Plato lamenting how his generation of youth is fucked with a general lack of virtue and respect, who seem to have very little attention spans. Wait sound familiar? So thought Hesiod in 8th century BC who cries about youth who are increasingly impatient of restraint.

But hey, if you disagree but you look at your phone a lot, just believe what I say because according to this video I guess I'm a better human being who's more virtuous and more purposeful in my existence.

Great video. I’ve adopted the habit of walking or riding instead of driving. Riding makes me a lot more aware of my surroundings but I find that the desire to improve often replaces any chance for deep thought (perhaps this is due to trips generally being less than 10 minutes.) Because waking is so much slower and more automatic, I find more time and opportunity to clear my head, reflect on what needs done and contemplate issues I’m facing. I spent about a year taking public transit to work and then walking home. Depending on the location, it could take upwards of five hours. The streets were quiet and I could observe, contemplate my surroundings and let my mind do what it needed. I listened to large parts of the Bible during this time and found that this environment aided recognizing new details that changed my perception and understanding. Being still internally does not require physical stillness. If you can learn to be still in quiet, you can then adopt it to noisy and distracting circumstances and let your mind work wherever you are. There are many more valuable things that come from stillness than were described in the video and if learn adopt it, the dim will fade and a grand vista will reveal itself.

Many good points here. However, I'm not certain that boredom and spending time with only your own thoughts are equivalent states. I view boredom as more of a state of ennui with your current situation/potential activities. Existing with your own thoughts without distractions can be boring, but I don't think that's an intrinsic condition. When I take time to let my mind wander it becomes an active condition. I become engaged. I feel like boredom exists when you are passive or disengaged.

A person can be scrolling through Facebook or watching a video or sitting in a meeting and be completely disengaged with their situation. Boredom can be having all sorts of entertainment options at your fingertips, but no urge to partake in them. It is also a part of the feeling of discomfort with just being with their thoughts. If you aren't uncomfortable with getting lost in thought, I feel like it isn't actually boredom, or perhaps the boredom lives in the time it takes to switch from engaging externally to engaging internally. I think that choice or a lack of it is a big factor in whether we find a situation boring and whether we take steps to mitigate that boredom.

What I definitely do agree with is that we are very averse to that feeling of discomfort and by moving away from it so quickly we miss out on opportunities for self refection. If we don't allow ourselves to get through that uncomfortable transition point from external to internal engagement, we have less chance to consider things deeply or make random connections that could be beneficial.

Or perhaps I just enjoy being with my own thoughts without distraction.

Errrm... I disagree with your interpretation of the results of the study. And your definition of boredom, I think. If you have something to think about, you're not bored. You're thinking. And if someone shocks themselves out of a desire to satisfy their curiosity about whether the button actually works, or how strong the shock is, or whether the institutions ERB would actually permit a study where participants can actually shock themselves, or whether they could prepare themselves enough for the shock that they could control their reaction to it, or many other possibilities, then they wouldn't be shocking themselves to avoid being left with their own thoughts. It is nearly impossible to guess the internal motivations of a person based on their actions and any attempt to do so usually amounts to showing off the lack of imagination of the person making the guess.

And when talking about how few people spent time relaxing and thinking, you say "apparently, because thinking is boring." That is not apparent at all. Not even close. We live in a society which aggressively dissuades thought. Why not claim that people don't murder others because 'apparently, it is boring'? No. People don't murder because there are social pressures not to murder, there are negative consequences to murdering, there are natural inhibitions against it, and a laundry list of other reasons. Similarly, people don't spend time thinking because there are social pressures not to, there are negative consequences to doing so, and many people are simply not capable of it because they've never been taught how or given any reason why they might want to.

Then you define boredom and directly contradict everything you've said before. 'Boredom is when your mind is not focused on anything in particular' is a direct contradiction of claiming that spending time thinking is boredom. If you are thinking about something, your mind is focused on that particular thing. I would agree that boredom is when your mind isn't focused on anything in particular and just wandering. But that, of course, means that the study had no controls or reason to believe that any of the participants were bored at all and probably has no relevance to the idea of boredom.

The phonebook study makes sense. If you are asked to read a phonebook, you're naturally going to try to alleviate or minimize the boredom of that. You might look for funny names, look for patterns in the numbers (which do exist, for a very long time only the digits 1 or 0 were legal middle digits for area codes and similar contraints existed for local exchanges), etc. You get your brain in a creative mood, actively working to find something interesting rather than passively just monitoring your perception. So you're primed to come up with ideas. I can get behind the idea that boredom motivates you to look for new things, but not that this will just lead you to escape internal mental activity in order to replace it with some external passive experience.

As for making you more altruistic, I would think it much more likely that "being bored" (AKA thinking) makes you more empathetic. When you are simply letting sensations fill your brain with perception, you're not considering the situation of others. You're not wondering what other people might be experiencing because you're focused only on whatever is happening in front of you. If you're busy dedicating your mind to just being, you're not considering how things could be different and you're certainly not considering what different situation other people might be in, let alone getting to the point where you might think you should try to help them in some way.

I've always found it true that "if you're bored, then you're boring." If you've got nothing going on in your head, you'll get bored. If you realize how rich and full of questions and interesting things the world is, you just can't be bored. If you're quiet and don't have some feed of ideas from someone else, your own ideas will be far more than enough to ensure you are never bored. You'll be more engaged and pick up all kinds of interesting things to share with other people. If you're just bored and either don't know how or aren't willing to guide your thoughts to thinking, you'll pick up very little and probably be a chore (and a bore) to be around.

I think this is why many of us turn to planned, deliberate "boredom" in the form of meditation and mindfulness. We make time for being bored to compensate for preventing boredom when it would otherwise naturally occur.

I know I've come to appreciate the feeling in recent years a lot more than I used to, and instead of desperately scrambling to find something to stave off agonising boredom I find it can be much more helpful to give up and just be bored for a while. And surprisingly, once I do, being bored becomes much less... boring. And after a while of spacing out I come back more alert, refreshed and motivated.

In some ways I see it like a switch between external and internal. We love external stimulation and really don't like it when we run out, but you can find entertainment inside your own head, too. Provided you aren't required to be very alert or focused on a difficult task, zoning out can be just as an effective timesink as watching TV or playing a game. So if you can tell your greedy consciousness to get lost for a bit when there's "nothing to do" you very rarely have to deal with worry of being bored.

I'm a mixture of both, but the thing is, I'm ALWAYS thinking. constantly. On my way to work, waiting in line, while I'm working, while I'm walking down a hallway, mid-conversation, while I'm gaming, even when I'm trying to fall asleep I'm always thinking. I think it stems from anxiety but I don't hate it at all. I think at a level that most people don't. I'm smarter than most people around me and I'm happy about that, and I can do that all while pulling out my phone every once in a while. it's like the best of both worlds. It's like how monks say you can mediate anywhere at any time, it's just a way of thought, that's basically me but instead of letting my thoughts flow away and emptying my worries, I let them consume me and flow through me at like 1,000,000 thoughts a minute. I've had some pretty deep thoughts on my own time, most people don't know how deep I am as a person because when they look at me they just see that quiet kid in class / at work.

The other day I watched the rain make ripples on a layer of water, and it struck me how long it had been since I was mentally and physically present with the rain. It felt like being reminded of a dormant part of myself which had been buried under the distractions of work and electronics. I attribute a lot of my contemplative creativity to the intervals of "boredom" I experienced growing up in the country without constant access to entertainment.
Too many people don’t know what to do with their own thoughts. People are over stimulated by the buzz of electronics, and forget to fine tune themselves to the subtler senses of life.

I'm a writer... I used to drive a truck from Spokane, Washington to Seattle and back once a week. I'd turn off the radio and think about scenes in my books. It was AMAZING!!! I'd get back at between 8PM Friday and 2AM Saturday, with DAYS of writing to do from all the thinking I'd gotten accomplished in the cab of that truck.

Once I stopped driving I thought I needed some way to replace that one day a week where I had to just be alone with my thoughts. This desire is why writers also tend to be walkers :-) Write in the morning... read in the afternoon... walk in the evening.

Another huge difference was turning off the TV. That thing will "time vampire" your life away.

Veritasium - You should read Bertrand Russel's book - In Praise of Idleness.

The creativity cup study is pretty suspect if you ask me. I read through their paper and they leave out all sorts of details of the experiment like: what the control group actually did do, what the instructions were for reading/writing tasks (how much were they encouraged to perform the task and why were they told to do so), which phonebook it was or what it actually looked like (local phonebook in a small town? [looking for names they recognize?]), could the creativity be due to a focused task like accurately transferring strings of random numbers?, etc.

There was also a pretty big discrepancy between their two studies and the "level of creativity in the answers" (how you even rate this close to objectively is beyond me) along with noted 'confusion' over the instructions for participants to rate their own suggestions by "creative usefulness". Another thing that stood out was that they only allowed people to go on to the creative cup idea portion who admitted to daydreaming during the writing task (isolating already creative people with strong imaginations?). I could go on and on, but I'm glad Veritasium cited the study in description so we can inform ourselves and not take everything at face value =D

These tests produce false positives in many situations. Those with higher IQs tend to become bored more easily. This is due to their minds not being satisfied with simple tasks such as listening to a lecture on matters they already know. These people will also tend to be more creative, due to them finding creativity more of a task and interest. People who are more easily bored also tend to excell or at least find interest in being creative. This is not in correlation with them also having been bored.

Boredom is doing something you do not want to do. Apparently many people don't like being alone with their own thoughts and Veritasium observes (correctly) that those people are bored then concludes (incorrectly) that being alone with one's own thoughts is boring.

Gardening is boring (to me) because I don't want to do it and it distracts me from thinking my own thoughts. Shopping is boring (to me) because I don't want to do it and it distracts me from thinking my own thoughts. Thinking my own thoughts isn't boring because I want to do it.

Don't confuse doing nothing but thinking with being bored. They are not the same thing even if many people find that doing nothing but letting their mind wander is boring.

My mind has always been a strange place. I swear the more I am doing something else the more my mind will cook up thoughts of things unrelated to what I'm doing but in a way it helps me focus even more on the task I'm doing physically at that same moment. So I've heard this idea a lot. That being bored has huge benefits that we are missing out on when we pick up our phone. I think there is a misunderstanding here. Being bored is a sign that we are not engaging our mind on any particular task. But picking up your cell phone I think is a priority Problem, not a boredom problem. I can use a phone 2 engage myself in creative activities like learning or writing a book. I can also use my phone to do activities that I find boring like planning my financial future or reading a manual for a piece of equipment that I need to use for work. The phone is not the problem. Being bored is simply a sign that you're not engaging your brain. It is true that when you are bored you're more likely to select an activity that you would be less likely to do if you had options that were more appealing to you personally. I really like sketching. I don't like watching football. But other people prefer the opposite. Some people find math exciting and engaging, but I don't think being bored is going to necessarily make you passionate about math. True if you're bored you may choose an activity but happens to be available that you didn't think you'd like, but as it turns out you found fascinating once you had tried it. It's also true that in the face of boredom I may choose to plan for my financial future so that I can spend more time scribbling in a notebook or playing a video game when that option becomes available. But I think that's more about time management and setting priorities. Anytime you are not engaging your mind and are "board" I think that's just your brainsway of telling you that you're not challenging yourself enough. But it's much more important to choose things that have the most benefit to you. Playing Angry Birds might engage your mind enough to Stave off boredom, but I think we all know that there are better uses of your time. Boredom is simply an indicator of the smaller problem, but videos like this seem to assign it some magical property that suggests if I sit in a room watching paint dry it's going to have massive benefits for my brain. But somebody who can be creative and a room watching paint dry can also be creative when doing the dishes. Or doing any task that does not use that portion of your mind. By focusing on boredom, and using it to turn mobile devices into the bad guy I think we miss out on what's really going on inside of our brains. Yes we could have better priorities, and we could spend less time on Angry Birds and Facebook... But that does not mean we need to be bored.

The thing about this generation is that we are so used to stimulus at our figure tips that it doesnt take us much to get bored. I use this to my advantage. At work I choose a day where I dont listen to music or see the news on my phone or pick up my phone. During that time where I would normally pick up my phone I get bored. So desperately bored. But some of my biggest successes in my career have come up as just a thought during these 1 day no phone days.  Boredom is so necessary for me as a scientist. We have a generation of people that their boredom is consumed buy a very easy thing to isolate. That's is actually pretty neat to exploit in one self and a work force. We are a generation of thinkers lets use that to move forward.
